Established in 1979, Gokaldas Exports Limited has emerged as one of India’s largest and most respected apparel manufacturers and exporters. With over four decades of experience, the company has built a formidable reputation for delivering high-quality apparel products to prestigious fashion brands and retailers across more than 50 countries. Gokaldas Exports is renowned for its robust in-house capabilities, state-of-the-art manufacturing facilities, and a strong commitment to sustainability. The Company operates over 30 state-of-the-art manufacturing facilities equipped with advanced technologies. These facilities are fully integrated, covering the entire value chain from design and development to cutting, sewing, printing, washing, and finishing. The company’s manufacturing prowess is supported by more than 30,000 operational machines spread across its facilities. One of Gokaldas Exports’ key strengths lies in its diverse and skilled workforce. The company employs over 51,000 people, with a significant proportion being women. This focus on inclusivity and empowerment is a cornerstone of the company’s operations and contributes to social upliftment in the communities where it operates.

A risk factor for Gokaldas Exports Limited due to significant revenue in USD, which exposes the company to exchange rate fluctuations, compounded by imported raw materials. Mitigation measures include robust hedging strategies and diversifying currency exposure.

A risk factor for Gokaldas Exports Limited involving changes in government policies or incentives (e.g., RoSCTL, EPCG, duty drawback) that could impact profitability. Mitigation measures include maintaining open dialogue with policymakers and diversifying market presence.

A risk factor for Gokaldas Exports Limited due to competitive disadvantage from the lack of free trade agreements with the EU, unlike some Asian counterparts. Mitigation measures include focusing on product differentiation and exploring strategic partnerships in EU countries.

A risk factor for Gokaldas Exports Limited involving volatility in fabric prices, wage inflation, and other input costs that can squeeze margins. Mitigation measures include implementing dynamic pricing models and strengthening supplier relationships.

A risk factor for Gokaldas Exports Limited due to rapidly changing fashion trends and consumer preferences requiring quick adaptability. Mitigation measures include enhancing design capabilities and implementing agile manufacturing processes.

A risk factor for Gokaldas Exports Limited due to reliance on a limited number of key customers for significant revenue. Mitigation measures include diversifying the customer base and investing in customer relationship management.

A risk factor for Gokaldas Exports Limited involving delays in raw material receipt that can impact production schedules and customer commitments. Mitigation measures include developing a robust supplier ecosystem and implementing advanced inventory management systems.

A risk factor for Gokaldas Exports Limited related to the ability to foresee and adapt to market shifts and evolving consumer behavior. Mitigation measures include investing in market research and fostering a culture of innovation.

Gokaldas Exports Limited is a company that has complied with various regulations, guidelines, and standards as mentioned in the report. It incorporated Gokaldas Exports Corporation in the U.S.A and Nava Apparels L.L.C-FZ in Dubai. It also allotted equity shares under the Gokaldas Exports Employee Restricted Stock Unit Plan, 2018, and acquired Amibros S.A. and Atraco Logistics Co LLC through Gokaldas Exports FZCO, Dubai, as well as Coast Apparel EPZ Limited, Ashton Apparel EPZ Limited and Mombasa Apparel EPZ Limited through Nava Apparels L.L.C-FZ. Additionally, the company allotted equity shares to Matrix Clothing Private Limited for acquiring Matrix Design & Industries Private Limited and invested in a renewable captive generating plant via Clean Max Celeste Private Limited. Special resolutions were passed at the Annual General Meeting and Extraordinary General Meeting, including the re-appointment of Sivaramakrishnan Ganapathi as Vice Chairman & Managing Director, the issuance of equity shares on a preferential basis, approval for raising funds through Qualified Institutions Placement (QIP), and amendments to the GEL Employee Stock Option Plan 2022. The company is also focused on energy conservation, implementing measures such as installing G2 Ozone machines, E-Flow machines, pad printing machines, and energy-efficient screen printing, replacing reciprocating compressors, simplifying tasks with efficient machinery, and upgrading old boilers. The company utilizes alternate energy sources, including a rooftop solar system and an Energy Supply Agreement (ESA) with Clean Max Celeste Private Limited for a captive power generation facility.

G2 Ozone machines utilize atmospheric air to reproduce ozone gas conditions to give garments a natural look. This technology significantly reduces water and energy usage while eliminating the need for polluting processes such as bleaching and permanganate usage.

E-Flow machines utilize nanobubbles of air to transmit chemicals into garments with minimal water and zero discharge. This innovative process eliminates the need for large amounts of hot water and steam typically required in wet processes, resulting in significant energy savings. e-Flow can reduce energy consumption by 15-25% compared to conventional garment finishing methods.

Renewable energy is a concept that Gokaldas Exports Limited is actively transitioning towards, aligning with its sustainability goals, as mentioned in the provided text. The company has in place a rooftop solar system in one of its units. In its pursuit to actively transition towards renewable energy, aligning with its sustainability goals, the board of the Company in October 2023 approved for Energy Supply Agreement (ESA) with Clean Max Celeste Private Limited a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV), for developing a captive power generation facility with 7.5 mw solar plant in the state of Karnataka.

Climate Change is identified as a risk by Gokaldas Exports Limited, necessitating the adoption of energy-efficient machineries, renewable energy sourcing, tree plantation drives, and the use of organic chemicals.

Gokaldas Exports Limited is an apparel manufacturing company that is focusing on responsible business conduct issues such as increasing solar energy sourcing, water management, circularity, human capital development, talent and skill management, responsible sourcing, and community engagement as described in the text.

Sustainability refers to the long-term maintenance and responsibility of environmental, social, and economic factors. Gokaldas Exports Limited is focusing on sustainability through various initiatives like water management, circularity, responsible sourcing, and community engagement.

Water management is a crucial aspect of the garment manufacturing industry due to its significant impact on both operational efficiency and environmental sustainability. Gokaldas Exports Limited is implementing measures to reduce fresh water demand, maximize water recycling using ZLD systems, install low liquor ratio and E-Flow laundry machines, explore rainwater harvesting, and use CETP treated water.
Zero Liquid Discharge (ZLD) systems are used to maximize water recycling potential. Gokaldas Exports Limited is implementing ZLD systems as part of its water management strategy.

E-Flow laundry machines are technologies that consume less water and chemicals, and generate low effluents. Gokaldas Exports Limited is installing E-Flow laundry machines as part of its water management strategy.

Circularity is crucial in mitigating the depletion of finite resources and reducing the environmental footprint of garment production. Gokaldas Exports Limited is working on improving design efficiency, implementing waste segregation, exploring upcycling, and increasing sourcing of recycled raw materials.

Human capital development is critical in labor-intensive manufacturing industries. Gokaldas Exports Limited is investing in livelihood opportunities, safe and inclusive work environments, employee well-being, and collaborations for skill development.

Skill development and talent management are essential in the labor-intensive apparel manufacturing sector. Gokaldas Exports Limited is implementing skill development programs, soft and technical skills upliftment for women, career progression roadmaps, and programs to promote women in leadership roles.

Responsible sourcing practices are vital due to their significant impact on sustainability, ethical standards, and compliance management. Gokaldas Exports Limited has started mapping of suppliers, developing guidelines on responsible sourcing and supply chain management, and initiating traceability and transparency programs.

Community engagement fosters trust, provides valuable local insights, creates beneficial partnerships, and strengthens the social license to operate. Gokaldas Exports Limited is engaging with local communities through CSR initiatives focused on healthcare, education, skill development, and community health improvement.

Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) initiatives are used for community engagement. Gokaldas Exports Limited is engaging with local communities through CSR initiatives focused on healthcare, education, skill development, and community health improvement.
Renewable energy is sourced by Gokaldas Exports Limited through increasing solar energy sourcing, achieving 100% fossil fuel replacement with biomass in boiler operations, and exploring wind energy.

Financial assets are categorized and measured at either amortised cost or fair value. Impairment losses are recognized based on expected credit losses. De-recognition occurs when contractual rights expire or assets are transferred, as described in the text.

Amortised cost is a method of measuring financial assets held within a business model aimed at collecting contractual cash flows, where these flows are solely payments of principal and interest, as mentioned in the text.

Fair value is a method used to measure financial assets, particularly those held within a business model aimed at collecting contractual cash flows or selling the assets. It is also used for financial liabilities initially, as described in the text.

Financial liabilities are classified based on contractual arrangements and are initially measured at fair value, then subsequently at amortised cost. De-recognition occurs when the obligation is discharged, cancelled, or expires, as detailed in the text.

Equity instruments are contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of the company after deducting all liabilities. They are recorded at the proceeds received, net of direct issue costs, as stated in the text.
Derivative financial instruments, such as foreign exchange forwards, are used to mitigate exchange rate risks. They are measured at fair value through profit or loss, as described in the text.

Foreign exchange forward contracts are used as cash flow hedges to mitigate foreign exchange exposure on forecast cash transactions. The effective portion of changes in fair value is recognized in other comprehensive income, as mentioned in the text.

Cash flow hedge accounting is used for foreign exchange forward contracts to mitigate foreign exchange exposure on forecast cash transactions. The effective portion of changes in fair value is recognized in other comprehensive income, as described in the text.

Market risk is defined as the potential for loss in future earnings, fair values, or cash flows due to changes in financial instrument prices, including interest rates, foreign currency exchange rates, and equity price fluctuations, as described in the Gokaldas Exports Limited Annual Report for the Financial Year 2023-24.

Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because of changes in market interest rates. Gokaldas Exports Limited manages this risk by maintaining a balanced portfolio of fixed and variable rate loans and borrowings.

Foreign currency risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of an exposure will fluctuate because of changes in foreign exchange rates. Gokaldas Exports Limited manages this risk by hedging transactions expected to occur within a maximum 12 months period using foreign currency forward contracts.

Credit risk is the risk that a counterparty will not meet its obligations under a financial instrument or customer contract, leading to a financial loss. Gokaldas Exports Limited manages customer credit risk through established policies, procedures, and controls, including impairment analysis for major customers.

Liquidity risk is the risk that Gokaldas Exports Limited cannot meet its financial obligations. The company manages this risk by maintaining sufficient liquidity, securing working capital lines from various banks, and investing surplus funds in low-risk assets.

Borrowing costs are defined as interest and other costs incurred in connection with the borrowing of funds, and they are either capitalized as part of the cost of an asset or expensed in the period they occur, according to the accounting policies of Gokaldas Exports Limited.

Leases are arrangements where the fulfillment depends on the use of a specific asset, and they are classified as either finance leases or operating leases, affecting how Gokaldas Exports Limited recognizes assets and liabilities.

Intangible assets are non-physical assets that are measured on initial recognition at cost and amortized over their useful economic life, with the amortization period and method reviewed annually.

Provisions are recognized when the Group has a present obligation (legal or constructive) as a result of a past event, it is probable that an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation and a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation.

A contingent liability is a possible obligation that arises from past events whose existence will be confirmed by the occurrence or non-occurrence of one or more uncertain future events beyond the control of the Group or a present obligation that is not recognised because it is not probable that an outflow of resources will be required to settle the obligation.
The Balance Sheet is a financial statement where provisions and contingent liabilities are reviewed, and where re-measurements of actuarial gains and losses are recognized, as described in the text.

Equity Instruments represents any contract that evidences a residual interest in the assets of Gokaldas Exports Limited after deducting all of its liabilities, as mentioned in the provided text. These are recorded at the proceeds received, net of direct issue costs.

Financial assets are recognized when Gokaldas Exports Limited becomes a party to the contract embodying the related financial instruments, as stated in the provided text. They are initially measured at transaction cost and, where different, at fair value. They can be measured at amortised cost or at fair value.

Financial liabilities are recognized when Gokaldas Exports Limited becomes a party to the contract embodying the related financial instruments, as stated in the provided text. They are initially measured at fair value, net of transaction costs, and are subsequently measured at amortised cost, using the effective interest rate method where the time value of money is significant.

Ind AS 109 is an accounting standard related to financial instruments, specifically addressing impairment and de-recognition of financial assets, as mentioned in the provided text. Gokaldas Exports Limited uses Ind AS 109 for impairment loss on investments.

Fair value is a measurement basis used for financial assets and liabilities, as described in the provided text. It is used in initial recognition and subsequent measurement of these instruments by Gokaldas Exports Limited.

The effective interest method is a method of calculating the amortised cost of a financial instrument and of allocating interest income or expense over the relevant period. The effective interest rate is the rate that exactly discounts future cash receipts or payments through the expected life of the financial instrument, or where appropriate, a shorter period.

Amortised cost is the cost at which financial assets are subsequently measured if these financial assets are held within a business model whose objective is to hold these assets in order to collect contractual cash flows and the contractual terms of the financial asset give rise on specified dates to cash flows that are solely payments of principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding.

The acquisition resulted in transfer of control w.e.f. March 13, 2024 and accounted for in accordance with Ind AS 103, Business Combination.

Gokaldas Exports Limited is a company that acquired 100% shareholding in Matrix Design and Industries Private Limited for a consideration of ` 32,306 lakhs settled through a combination of cash consideration of ` 7,557 lakhs and preferential allotment of 27,31,366 equity shares of Gokaldas Exports Limited at a price of 906.14 per share. The acquisition resulted in transfer of control w.e.f. March 13, 2024 and accounted for in accordance with Ind AS 103, Business Combination. The company had executed certain agreements with Clean Max Enviro Energy Solutions Private limited and Clean Max Celeste Private Limited (SPV), including a share purchase agreement for investment in a renewable Captive Generating Plant. This involved an investment in a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV), a private limited Company through an acquisition of 26% stake through an investment of ` 315 lakhs (Indian Rupees Three hundred and fifteen lakhs) by way of an equity share capital contribution in the SPV, the arrangement also involves certain power purchase arrangements, basis the evaluation of the terms of the aforementioned agreements, the Company has assessed and classified this as an investment and is recorded at fair value. Subsequent to the year ended March 31, 2024, on April 24, 2024, the Company raised money by way of Qualified Institutional Placement ('QIP') and allotted 77,41,935 equity shares of face value ` 5/- each to the eligible qualified institutional buyers ('QIB') at a price of ` 775/-per share (Including a premium of ` 770 per share) aggregating to ` 60,000 lakhs on April 23, 2024. This issue was made in accordance with SEBI (Issue of Capital and Disclosure Requirements) Regulation, 2018. The Board of Directors of the Company at their meeting held on May 25, 2023 had recommended a final dividend of ` 1/- (one rupee only) per equity share (i.e. 20% of face value of ` 5 per equity share) for the financial year ended March 31, 2023. The dividend recommended by the Board of Directors was approved by the shareholders at the Annual General Meeting of the Company held on September 20, 2023 and was subsequently paid. During the year the Company (Ultimate Beneficiary) provided loans to its wholly owned subsidiaries 'Gokaldas Exports FZCO' and 'Nava Apparels LLC' (Intermediaries). The terms of these transactions have been documented in writing. On January 03, 2024, the Intermediaries directly invested in other entities identified by the Ultimate Beneficiary for the purpose of acquiring the ATRACO group (refer note 44(i)). There has been no violation or non-compliance with the relevant provisions of the Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999 (42 of 1999), Prevention of Money-Laundering act, 2002 (15 of 2003), or the Companies Act, 2013 in relation to these transactions.

Financial Year 2023-24 is the period for which the consolidated financial statements are presented in the text. During the year ended March 31, 2024, the Holding Company has acquired 100% shareholding in Matrix Design and Industries Private Limited (“MDIL”) for a consideration of ` 32,306 lakhs settled through a combination of cash consideration of ` 7,557 lakhs and preferential allotment of 27,31,366 equity shares of Gokaldas Exports Limited at a price of 906.14 per share. The acquisition resulted in transfer of control w.e.f. March 13, 2024 and accounted for in accordance with Ind AS 103, Business Combination. Mr. Prabhat Kumar Singh is a person with four decades of experience in the apparel and textile sector. He has held leadership positions in the textile industry and industry bodies like the Apparel Export Promotion Council (AEPC). He has steered the corporate development function of Gokaldas Exports Limited over the last 5 years and played a significant role in interfacing with the industry, and various regulatory authorities, including project implementation under the Government schemes, modernization, technology and infrastructure upgradation for textiles and funding support. He was instrumental in setting up the new apparel manufacturing plant in Madhya Pradesh (Gokaldas Exports Acharpura Private Limited) and Tamil Nadu (Sri Susamyuta Knits Private Limited). He graduated from Banaras Hindu University and completed his MBA from XLRI, Jamshedpur. He also holds a Diploma in International Marketing from Buckinghamshire College (UK).
